title: Timing attack towards endpoints on the web without CSRF

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

activities.message:
^^ 
```
From measured time, we can get conclusion even for the number of reports / records in the response if we divide the content size with average size of one (json) record. :)
```

Should be:

From measured time, we can get conclusion even for the number of reports / records in the response if we divide the `calculated` content size with average size of one (json) record - we can find an average due the fact many of the properties are with fixed length and few are variable which size doesn't affect the proximity. :)

Hi @slavco - thanks for your report, this looks pretty promising! For the sake of a proof of concept, would you mind providing a PoC that tries to guess the number of reports for the `security` program in the `new`, `triaged`, and `resolved` state? Thanks in advance, it's much appreciated!

Hi, I have created a very simple demo that calculations are based on average values ( not employed good numerical methods for better estimation, but will be in future ofc. ).

Demo url data dumps generated ( measured time - directory listing is enabled ):
https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/data/ 

How to use:

I have performed tests against: 

https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=33&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged

`text_query` must have at least one character, due complexity on server side - returns lower values.
When you decide regarding your endpoint, then visit the following urls one by one:

1. https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/1.php
2. https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/2.php
3. https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/3.php?query=33 - this call must have parameter `query` which will be the same as `text_query` you use.
4. Visit them one by one
5. Visit https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/miner.php 
6. If you have stable internet connection then change the `query` parameter and verify results on your side opening 
`https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=GET_QUERY_VARIABLE&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged`
e.g. `1.php` and `2.php` will almost always return same results.

More stable internet connection, better results, but if you don't have stable internet connection then for every demo reload 1.php, 2.php and 3.php?query=your_val.
 
Demo is based on simple average values and doesn't find filed or prolonged requests, but it is quite easy to be implemented...
Don't forget to run in the exact order and to supply desired `query` GET parameter on 3.php . See the attachments :)
Bonus: only one person at the time should test this... Forgot that dumps are hard-coded, but will do the job for PoC

Also open a console on your web browser, you can monitor the harvested response times being send towards "attacker" server and verify them under https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/data/ (filenames are descriptive)

Regarding the final e.g. very good exploit for this vulnerability would require creating smarter JS client ( dynamic and timed creation of `` elements, optimization of internet connection speed measurement, filtering of failed or prolonged requests based on the retrieved data, better estimation of size of the record due it is send gzip-ed and few another aspects ), but overall it works. From use cases I have think about, beside minimg, could also be used as CSRF exploitation of blind SQLi.

Hi @slavco - it might actually work, but because the `subject` is empty, so it'll always default to an empty set. The first time I ran it, it gave me -22 records, the seconds time -1. Would you mind updating the `subject` to `security` on your server so I can test this with actual reports? Thanks! I'm wondering how practical this is to actually determine the contents of a report through searching, but being able to get the counts would already be pretty cool. Thanks!

Changed :) 
The trick is you need to hit f5 few times, first 1, 2 and last 3.php . As I mentioned atm it takes average value without cleaning the edge values - data clustering on this values using cosine similarity will do the job more than good :)
I can send you the code, so you can play locally. Just second to upload the scripts here.
place them where you want and next to them create web writable `data` directory :)

In the `miner.php` 185B hardcoded value is average value of one record from json array. It is considered fact that responses are gzip-ed and that is why there is 2100B (some request with 1+ records) -800B (estimated empty response) / 7 (number of records in my case) in order to get some approximation. I need it to multiply with the speed per calculated average time. With better measurements and clustering results will be quite effective.

If you run the scripts locally intervene in the .txt files to remove the edge values and you will have the results with the user endpoint. Also change the 185B variable for `security` parameter appropriately. Another interesting thing I have noticed is server side complexity on H1 is far lower when `text_query` doesn't have any value, so when you test, make sure it has one :)

Hi @slavco - hmm, I like your approach a lot, but I can't get it to be as precise as I want to for it to be a security vulnerability. I've reduced the number of `img` tags per page load to 10 to avoid the browser to wait for other request to finish, which artificially increases the RTT. This is not something you want for it to be used when calculating the averages. However, when doing so, I'm still getting relatively high numbers compared to what I should get. I'm seeing results of 50 reports whereas the actual search only returns 7 items. Any other ideas on how to make it more precise? Otherwise I'm leaning towards closing this out as informative for the time being. I'm happy to throw in some swag for your efforts and approach, I love the creativity!

The issue is here, the only missing thing is working exploit wich would be created with more measurements and better approximations. let me create video for you. 
Regarding img elements, measurment would be best if they are created and measured dynamic one by one, and on that values to be performed calculations
Video is rendering atm, simple F5 towards scripts one by one and results are there :)
Rendered video has failed, new one is rendering. Results are more than fine :)

Same old bad rendering of screen recorder, but miner not rounded values could be seen and endpoints from my account are the following:
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=33&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged - 3 reports
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged - 7 reports
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=4&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged -5 reports
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=40&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged - 1 report

All of them were guessed with this employed basic approximations. Issue exists atm and is caused by the fact that url could be guessed e.g. there isn't token in it. 
I think should be considered as a issue, due the fact interesting information is leaked.

Extra from my side: there are programs that even one triaged / open issue could be interesting indicator. The scripts as they are could calculate the minimum with few probings or to tell `x+` issues, but as you can see they give exact number as they are.

Hi @slavco - thanks for following up. I have unfortunate news, and you can blame me for it personally. While going throw your report I realized that I had seen it before, but it was a while back (4 years to be exact). The endpoints changed (`/reports` became `/bugs`) overtime, but the attack is still the same. I'm going ahead and add you to the original report. We'll have an internal discussion if it's time to revisit our earlier decision to punt on the fix. I'm sorry to have asked you all these questions, it wasn't my intention to end up closing it as a duplicate. Because of that, I'll throw in some swag here. We're looking forward to receive more reports from you in the future. Again, apologies from my end. Good luck and happy hacking!
We'll send you some cool goodies!

Thx for the swag, but must agree that my report goes much beyond another ones - delivers information, even delivers real results. I still don't agree with the duplicate. I'll continue my research for sure ( I have mentioned clustering and numerical analysis  ), but I was hoping that I would continue it relaxed. Nvm, let it flow :)

Yeah, I'm not disagreeing with that, but the problem is the same. Different ways of exploiting it doesn't mean the root cause isn't the same (e.g. we allow `GET` requests to query this type of information). @cache-money, who also filed a duplicate, was also able to show results. I'd encourage you to continue the research, but if it comes down to rewarding a bounty, we'd reward the original finder. We might throw in a bonus, but that wouldn't be the same as the original bounty. I'm happy to be convinced that we need to fix this. Until then, we'll keep it closed as Informative. Good luck and I'm looking forward to your findings!

Ha, interesting feature of the attack surface!
Attack surface is based on time => all we need is timing of the victim and nothing more - calculations are done on the server side or offline. If I send some link toward someone and I want to know how many reports are new, triaged, closed in certain period of time  ( id of the report is incremental numeric value ).

So, in order to get the right answer regarding this information ( victim number of reports per type / period of time ) we need to measure the following:

a. Timing towards "empty" response e.g. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=99999999999999999999&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged
b. Timing towards endpoint from which we need to extract data e.g. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged

How we will extract data: 
1. we measure the responses from our end
2. From (a) timing results we get knowledge regarding the internet speed of the victim towards H1 servers at the time
3. From (b) timing we derive the results in the form of response size and due the fact we can estimate each record size => we have number of records.

I think not it is more clear why this report is very very different than another ones. 
 - It strictly says that need to be added CSRF tokens in the request.   
 - It exploits the report id as time traveling value 

Regarding the statement that root cause is already reported I would like to state that my approach most probably has already pushed updates towards the system and those reports are very very old. That is why I'm continuing my research and I continue with strong arguments why report should be separate. Btw I haven't meet this type of attack anywhere else, just got inspired by that http 500 null string error :)

> I'm continuing my research and I continue with strong arguments why report should be separate

I'm not convinced yet that this is a separate issue, but feel free to continue to look at it and proof me wrong. It's a known vulnerability that the RTT of some endpoints can be used to determine the number of objects. However, we've fine with this, which is why we closed the original report as Informative. Even if this wouldn't be a duplicate, we'd still close it as Informative. Only if you'd find something crazy we'd be prioritizing this and we'd be happy to give you credit for finding something we didn't know about yet. Looking forward to hearing more from you in the future!

I have filled in separate report 350432 and named it Information disclosure, it carefully describes the attack surface (here I had many points and most probably complete conversation is more than confusing ). If you still think it is fine with anyone that any logged in person on HackerOne risks disclosure of number critical reports triaged last week towards 3rd party web site as a fine with you, then ok, let it be informative and we can make the report public 350432. I think it has very bigger impact than grade you give it, so I would like to make a nice technical write up. Is it ok?

summaries.content:
[mslavco](https://twitter.com/mslavco) submitted a report to us that identified a way to extract certain information about reports. In our testing the method was not reliable enough to exploit this in the wild, which is why no fix was prioritized. In 2019 this endpoint will likely be deprecated and we'll move to GraphQL to query the information. This new endpoint will require a token, which means it won't be susceptible to the described attack. We'd like to thank [mslavco](https://twitter.com/mslavco) for their report.

Even though we don't publicly disclose reports that weren't closed as Resolved, we're making an exception here for transparency's sake. Multiple accusations, by different actors, have been made of harassment, hate speech and discrimination by the reporter. We've investigated the accusations and determined that this was not the case.

Also see #350432.
